dataset.title: Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest: Valleywide Plot Tree and Sapling Inventory – 1995, 2005, 2015

abstract.para: The valley-wide plots are a grid of 431 sites along fifteen N–S transects established at 500-m intervals spanning the entire Hubbard Brook Valley. The plot network was designed by Paul Schwarz for spatial analysis of tree species distribution patterns within the valley. Multiple above- and below-ground attributes have been measured on these plots. This dataset includes forest inventory data at 10 year intervals, for 1995, 2005, and 2015. The full survey takes three seasons to complete, with the datatable listing the exact measurement interval for each tree.
Data are included for both trees and saplings on 371 core plots (all surveys) and 60 densified plots (1998, 2008).
Locations of plots in this study can be found in the following dataset:
Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest Valleywide Plots: GIS Shapefile (2022.)

These data were gathered as part of the Hubbard Brook Ecosystem Study (HBES). The HBES is a collaborative effort at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, which is operated and maintained by the USDA Forest Service, Northern Research Station.
These data have been used in a number of publications including:

Schwarz, P.A., Fahey, T.J., Martin, C.W., Siccama, T.G., and Bailey, A. 2001. Structure and composition of three northern hardwood–conifer forests with differing disturbance histories. For. Ecol. Manage. 144(1–3): 201–212. doi:10.1016/S0378-1127(00)00371-6.

Schwarz, P.A., Fahey, T.J., and McCulloch, C.E. 2003. Factors controlling spatial variation of tree species abundance in a forested landscape. Ecology, 84(7): 1862–1878. doi:10.1890/0012-9658(2003)084[1862:FCSVOT]2.0.CO;2.

van Doorn, N.S., Battles, J.J., Fahey, T.J., Siccama, T.G., and Schwarz, P.A. 2011. Links between biomass and tree demography in a northern hardwood forest: a decade of stability and change in Hubbard Brook Valley, New Hampshire. Can. J. For. Res. <emphasis role="strong">41</emphasis>(7): 1369–1379. doi:10.1139/X11-063.
Cleavitt, NL; AB Clyne and TJ Fahey. 2019. Epiphytic macrolichen patterns along an elevation gradient in the White Mountain National Forest, New Hampshire. J. Torrey Bot. Soc. 146(1): 8-17.

Cleavitt, NL; Battles, JJ, Fahey, TJ, and Blum, J. 2014. Determinants of survival over seven years for a natural cohort of sugar maple seedlings in a northern hardwood forest. Can. J. For. Res.44 (9): 1112-1121.

intellectualRights.para: This information is released under the Creative Commons license - Attribution - CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

description.para: The methods for the collection of these data are provided in 2 pdf files in this data package.

project.title: Long-term Ecological Research (LTER) at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest (1992)

attribute.attributeDefinition: key that identifies plots on main grid (CORE) and plots that are part of densified network. Core grid: 500 m along slope; 100 then 200 with elevation)

codeDefinition.definition: Plot as part of densified network

attribute.attributeDefinition: Radius of plot in m. 12.62 m is standard; 10 m for high density plots
Time interval in years; first interval
Time interval in years; second interval

codeDefinition.definition: mixed forest dominated by red maple, eastern hemlock and yellow birch
mixed forest dominated by red spruce and yellow birch
northern hardwood forest dominated by sugar maple, American beech and yellow birch
mixed forest initially dominated by paper birch and balsam fir
conifer forest dominated by red spruce

attribute.attributeDefinition: Sampling interval where the tree tree was first observed. Because of trees that were missed in earlier sampling intervals, andobserved later the time of first observation does not always correspond to year of recruitment. We backcast DBH of MISSED trees

codeDefinition.definition: tree first observed in first sampling cycle
tree first observed in second sampling cycle
tree first observed in third sampling cycle

attribute.attributeDefinition: The current tree tag on the tree in the woods as of the 2015 sampling interval

textDomain.definition: The current tree tag on the tree in the woods as of the 2015 sampling interval

attribute.attributeDefinition: Two letter species code of the final species assignment. Always defer to Nat Cleavitt checks
DBH of tree in cm in first interval
Crown status of tree in first interval
Tree status of tree in first interval

codeDefinition.definition: dead, standing without significant degredation and decay

attribute.attributeDefinition: DBH of tree in cm in second interval
Crown status of tree in second interval
Tree status of tree in second interval

codeDefinition.definition: dead, standing without significant degredation and decay

attribute.attributeDefinition: DBH of tree in cm in third interval
Crown status of tree in third interval
Tree status of tree in third interval

codeDefinition.definition: dead, standing without significant degredation and decay

attribute.attributeDefinition: Assessment of beech bark disease progression in 2015 (third interval)

codeDefinition.definition: no signs of BBD, bark smooth
BBD present, but does not affect DBH measurement; lower bole mostly uncankered
BBD present:1-3 cankers affect DBH measurement
BBD present: 3+ cankers distorts DBH measurement
synonymous with 4 but initially used in 2015
Cankers have coalesced and trunk is completely disfigured usually with canopy dieback

attribute.attributeDefinition: Time in years between first and second inventory; general 10 but varies from 8 to 11
Time in years between second and third inventory; always 10
Elevation zone used for biomass calculation
Species in old two letter code; Same as Species_BEST_15
Designates whether species is a hardwood or conifer species
Desingates five most abundant tree species:ABBA,ACSA, BEAL, FAGR, PIRU

codeDefinition.definition: does not belong to the five most common species; less frequent species
belongs to the five most common species: Americn beech, sugar maple, yellow birch, red spruce and balsam fir

attribute.attributeDefinition: DBH size class in cm range
midpoint of DBH size class in cm

codeDefinition.definition: dead, standing without significant degredation and decay
